title: Indian editors decry government move to police online news
summary: The Editors Guild of India has expressed serious concerns over the government's new fact-checking unit that will monitor online content about the government and flag items it considers false, calling it an attempt to control the press.
content:
Indian news media leaders have voiced strong opposition to the government's latest initiative to regulate online news content. The newly announced fact-checking unit, given authority to flag and demand removal of content deemed false about the government, has sparked widespread concern among journalists and media organizations.

The Editors Guild of India criticized the move as a concerning development that could potentially restrict press freedom and independent journalism. The organization warns that giving a government body the power to determine truth in news could lead to censorship and compromise editorial independence.

This development comes amid growing tensions between Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government and news organizations over press freedoms and content regulation in the world's largest democracy.

## Press Freedom Concerns

Indian news media leaders have voiced strong opposition to the government's latest initiative to regulate online news content. The newly announced fact-checking unit, given authority to flag and demand removal of content deemed false about the government, has sparked widespread concern among journalists and media organizations.

The Editors Guild of India criticized the move as a "concerning development" that could potentially restrict press freedom and independent journalism. The organization warns that giving a government body the power to determine truth in news could lead to censorship and compromise editorial independence.

This development comes amid growing tensions between Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government and news organizations over press freedoms and content regulation in the world's largest democracy.
